articles.headline: Nasdaq Sets Aside $40 Million to Settle Facebook Claims
articles.snippet: The Nasdaq OMX Group plans to set aside up to $40 million to settle disputes by investors over issues caused by technical glitches in Facebook’s initial public offering.
articles.abstract: The Nasdaq OMX Group plans to set aside up to $40 million to settle disputes by investors over issues caused by technical glitches in Facebook’s initial public offering.
articles.lead_paragraph: 9:28 p.m. | Updated The Nasdaq OMX Group is taking its first step to quell investor anger over the flawed debut of Facebook shares last month — pledging $40 million to cover broker losses — but some customers and competitors quickly raised objections.
articles.byline: By Michael J. de la Merced and Nathaniel Popper

articles.headline: Companies Try to Create Room on Radio Spectrum
articles.snippet: Technology that allows the sharing of frequencies is getting new backing as smartphones and tablets put greater demand on available bands.
articles.abstract: Technology that allows the sharing of frequencies is getting new backing as smartphones and tablets put greater demand on available bands.
articles.lead_paragraph: Cellphone carriers like AT&T and Verizon say they are worried about running out of the radio spectrum that carries wireless calls and data, and they want the government to give them more chunks of it. But a number of companies are developing technology that could change the whole spectrum game by using radio frequencies more efficiently.

articles.headline: Goodbye, MobileMe. Hello, Jimdo.
articles.snippet: Apple’s MobileMe service is scheduled to end on June 30. Here are possible replacements for its photo/video galleries, Web page building tools and online hard drives.
articles.abstract: Apple’s MobileMe service is scheduled to end on June 30. Here are possible replacements for its photo/video galleries, Web page building tools and online hard drives.
articles.lead_paragraph: If this is Thursday, Apple must be revamping its online services again.

articles.headline: Goldman Sachs Expected to Name Fewer Partners
articles.snippet: The firm’s decision to name fewer partners comes as dozens of partners have announced plans to leave in a steady exodus over the last year.
articles.abstract: The firm’s decision to name fewer partners comes as dozens of partners have announced plans to leave in a steady exodus over the last year.
articles.lead_paragraph: As Goldman Sachs shrinks, its elite inner circle will also be getting smaller.

articles.headline: U.S. Attacks, Online and From the Air, Fuel Secrecy Debate
articles.snippet: Leaks about drones and cyberattacks, two weapons that by many accounts have devastated Al Qaeda and set back Iran’s nuclear effort, have angered lawmakers in both parties.
articles.abstract: Leaks about drones and cyberattacks, two weapons that by many accounts have devastated Al Qaeda and set back Iran’s nuclear effort, have angered lawmakers in both parties.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In recent years, the United States has pioneered the use of two innovative weapons, drones and cyberattacks, that by many accounts have devastated Al Qaeda and set back Iran’s nuclear effort.

articles.headline: Bill Pushes for Increase in Wages
articles.snippet: Representative Jesse L. Jackson Jr. proposed that raising the federal minimum wage might encourage Americans to spend more, which would help stimulate the economy.
articles.abstract: Representative Jesse L. Jackson Jr. proposed that raising the federal minimum wage might encourage Americans to spend more, which would help stimulate the economy.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Representative Jesse L. Jackson Jr. tried to give new vitality to the issue of the federal minimum wage on Wednesday, coming at the debate with a fresh angle: that raising it might encourage Americans to spend more and, thus, help stimulate the nation’s struggling economy.

articles.headline: Spain Holds a Trump Card in Bank Bailout Negotiations
articles.snippet: The euro zone’s fourth-largest economy is too big to fail and possibly too big to steamroll, changing the balance of power in bargaining over a deal to rescue Spain’s ailing banks.
articles.abstract: The euro zone’s fourth-largest economy is too big to fail and possibly too big to steamroll, changing the balance of power in bargaining over a deal to rescue Spain’s ailing banks.
articles.lead_paragraph: BERLIN — The bargaining has begun over a deal to rescue Spain’s ailing banks, confronting Europe with urgent choices about whether to try to enforce onerous bailout terms on Madrid as the crisis spreads to the region’s largest economies.
articles.byline: By Nicholas Kulish and Raphael Minder

articles.headline: DNA Blueprint for Fetus Built Using Tests of Parents
articles.snippet: Researchers put together most of a fetus’s genome using a mother’s blood and father’s saliva, heralding an era when parents might know much more about a child long before its birth.
articles.abstract: Researchers put together most of a fetus’s genome using a mother’s blood and father’s saliva, heralding an era when parents might know much more about a child long before its birth.
articles.lead_paragraph: For the first time, researchers have determined virtually the entire genome of a fetus using only a blood sample from the pregnant woman and a saliva specimen from the father.

articles.headline: San Diego and San Jose Lead Way in Pension Cuts
articles.snippet: Now that voters in San Diego and San Jose have overwhelmingly passed pension cuts for city workers, other struggling cities may follow suit.
articles.abstract: Now that voters in San Diego and San Jose have overwhelmingly passed pension cuts for city workers, other struggling cities may follow suit.
articles.lead_paragraph: While the eyes of the nation focused on Wisconsin, where Gov. Scott Walker brushed back a recall attempt by critics of his move to strip most public-sector unions of their collective bargaining rights, a pair of less noticed local elections Tuesday in California could have more immediate ramifications for struggling state and local governments and for organized labor.
articles.byline: By Michael Cooper and Mary Williams Walsh

articles.headline: Rather Than Share Your Location, Foursquare Wants to Suggest One
articles.snippet: Foursquare, a start-up whose app lets users share their locations, has seen its growth slow, and its founders hope that suggesting places to users could change that.
articles.abstract: Foursquare, a start-up whose app lets users share their locations, has seen its growth slow, and its founders hope that suggesting places to users could change that.
articles.lead_paragraph: Two years ago, Foursquare was the star of the New York start-up scene. Celebrities and major brands embraced its mobile app, and companies like Facebook and Yahoo were eager to buy it.

articles.headline: Syrians Bar U.N. Monitors From a Massacre Inquiry
articles.snippet: The Syria conflict moved to a dangerous new precipice when government troops and civilian supporters blocked unarmed United Nations monitors from looking into a mass killing.
articles.abstract: The Syria conflict moved to a dangerous new precipice when government troops and civilian supporters blocked unarmed United Nations monitors from looking into a mass killing.
articles.lead_paragraph: ANTAKYA, Turkey — The Syrian conflict escalated to a dangerous new level on Thursday when government troops and their civilian supporters blocked unarmed United Nations monitors from investigating a massacre of farm families, prompting sharp denunciations of Damascus from diplomats who have struggled vainly to find a workable, consensus solution to the crisis.
articles.byline: By Neil MacFarquhar and Rick Gladstone

articles.headline: China Cuts Lending Rate as Its Economic Growth Slows
articles.snippet: The central bank’s action is the strongest measure taken by Chinese officials this year to counteract the economic malaise that has already infected Europe and the United States.
articles.abstract: The central bank’s action is the strongest measure taken by Chinese officials this year to counteract the economic malaise that has already infected Europe and the United States.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Faced with a sharply slowing economy, weak exports and faltering investment, China’s central bank unexpectedly announced Thursday that it would cut interest rates by a quarter of a percentage point.

articles.headline: Bernanke Offers No Clear Sign of New Action
articles.snippet: Lackluster jobs data and economic storm clouds have not convinced Federal Reserve officials that growth is slowing or that they should respond, the Fed’s chairman, Ben S. Bernanke, said on Thursday.
articles.abstract: Lackluster jobs data and economic storm clouds have not convinced Federal Reserve officials that growth is slowing or that they should respond, the Fed’s chairman, Ben S. Bernanke, said on Thursday.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Lackluster jobs data and storm clouds on the economic horizon have not yet convinced Federal Reserve officials that growth is slowing, nor that they should respond, the Fed’s chairman, Ben S. Bernanke, said on Thursday.
